repository.label: Repository

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Gift of Arturo Islas, 1985, and the Estate of Arturo Islas, 1991 & 1992.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: [Identification of item] Arturo Islas Papers , M0618, Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Arturo Islas was an English professor at Stanford and an author who explored the Chicano experience of living in two cultures in his novels. He was born on May 24, 1938 in El Paso, Texas, and left with a Sloan Scholarship and to study at Stanford University in 1956. He had intended to become a neurosurgeon, but his ambitions in the sciences gave way to his exceptional talents in literature. Referring to this switch, he once said, So it was that the poor Chicano boy came to teach the Anglos their literature. He graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in English, Phi Beta Kappa, in 1960, and entered the Ph. D. program in the autumn. In 1971, upon completion of his dissertation on Jewish-American novelist Hortense Calisher, Arturo Islas became the first Chicano in the United States to earn a doctorate in English.

Arturo Islas stayed at Stanford and distinguished himself as a teacher, winning the Dinkelspiel Award for Outstanding Service to Undergraduate Education in 1976. That same year, he became Stanford's first tenured Chicano faculty member. Both in and outside the classroom, Islas was a major force in nurturing the growing Chicano community. He was an advisor to many Chicano students, taught courses geared toward their needs and interests, and was active in numerous Chicano organizations. Better known for his courses on American literature, he was a popular lecturer and was elected to speak at Senior Class Day four times.

Outside the Stanford comnmunity, Islas won fame for his two novels,
The Rain God, which garnered numerous awards, and
Migrant Souls, published in 1990.
Migrant Souls was the first novel by a Chicano to be published by a New York firm. After his long struggle against the New York firms to have his Chicano voice heard, his reaction was more of outrage than pride at having cracked the system. In the trilogy of books he was writing, he chronicled three generations of a fictitious Mexican-American family not unlike his own, struggling with cultural duality. His lyrical novels were a new and strong voice for the Mexican American experience.

Arturo Islas was working on
La Mollie and the King of Tears, the last book of the trilogy, and another novel, tentatively titled
American Dreams and Fantasies when he died of AIDS related complications on February 15, 1991.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The bulk of this collection consists of correspondence, manuscripts, teaching and subjects materials Arturo Islas kept on file in his years teaching and writing at Stanford. The collection also includes materials relating Chicano issues, particularly the Chicano community at Stanford University. Unless indicated as outgoing correspondence, the letters in files are incoming.
This first series contains biographical notes, his curriculum vitae, and miscellaneous personal items. Also included is health information, particularly about AIDS.

This second series contains mostly incoming, personal correspondence from 1964-1991. The correspondence takes form in letters, cards, and postcards, with some photographs. They are organized by year, with the exception of a few files Islas kept by correspondent. The correspondents consist of friends, family members, colleagues, and students. Some of his personal correspondence may also be found in the people files he kept. There are also a few business letters that Islas had not catalogued in his subject files.

This third series contains manuscripts and drafts from Islas's published books,
The Rain God - A Desert Tale, Migrant Souls, and two works in progress:
La Mollie and the King of Tears, the last of the trilogy, and
American Dreams and Fantasies, a separate novel. Also included in the series are poems, book reviews, and miscellaneous writings by Islas, correspondence with his agent, Sandy Dijkstra, his publishers at the Alexandrian Press and William Morrow, readers' responses, and book reviews for his novels.

This fourth series contains Islas's notebooks from his years at Stanford as a student. His notebooks and classwork files contain notes, papers, and exams, mostly from English classes, from 1957-1962. This series also contains his Ph. D. dissertation,
Hortense Calisher: On Middle Ground.

This fifth series contains Islas's subject files. These are grouped as files of literary figures, teaching/class files, business files (speeches, conferences, and business related activities), Stanford-related files (speeches, awards, and committees), files pertaining to the Stanford Chicano community and Chicano issues, and miscellaneous subject files. Islas kept an alphabetical file of literary figures which contain lectures he used in class. His teaching/class files include files of the many classes he taught, with notes and admistrative papers. The Chicano-related files contain papers on classes, activities, and organizations Islas was involved in, news and magazine articles on Chicano issues. Among these, Islas kept thorough files on Richard Rodriguez and Danny Santiago, two controversial Chicano writers.

This sixth series contains Islas's files on colleagues (mostly from Stanford) and other people of interest, friends, graduate and undergraduate students. The graduate student files mostly contain orals notes and letters of recommendation, and the undergraduates, letters of recommendation and related information.
This seventh series contains videotapes and audiotapes of interviews and readings of Islas, and two inspirational journals.
This eighth series contains photographs of Islas, friends, etc. and some artwork by friends. The photographs are mostly snapshots, with some professional black and white photos of Islas.
This ninth series contains oversize materials from the collection. It consists mostly framed photos, artwork, and awards, and some miscellaneous items.
